Message:
Basic: Pages with static information and it can cost about $3K.

Medium Complexity: Pages with static information, few functional units, and API, third-party integration. it can cost from $10K.

Complex: All from ‘Medium’, Multiple user roles, High user load and Custom statistics. It may cost about $25K.

Web application cost estimation is a thorny issue because clients instantly want to hear an accurate figure, and companies try to explain why it doesn't work like that. Both sides insist they are right. The cost of creating a web app is composed of the number of work hours put into it, multiplied by the hourly rate of your web development team. The number of work hours that your team will need to develop your app will mostly depend on its complexity. Developers in USA, Canada, the UK, and Australia can be hired to make a web app for $80-250/hour.

Eastern Europe, Middle East, and South America come second with $30-110 per hour. The cheaper option is to hire developers from Ukraine for $20-50 or India for $10-80 per hour.

The oversimplified estimations of the three types of projects based on their complexity are given below.

Some examples I can think of off the top of my head are the Linux kernel and Git SCM.

The kernel uses C extensively. Except for the architecture code, it uses C. The Git SCM is written in C but it also uses a lot of shell scripts.
This is a full flight simulator for a modern commercial aircraft. Almost every part of it is written in C or C++ including the real avionics.

Adam D'Angelo, a Quora founder, answer this question at Why did Quora choose Python for its development?.

I would summarize his answer as:

  • The founders didn't like Microsoft, so C# was out.
  • Java takes longer and is harder to write, and doesn't operate well with non-Java stuff.
  • OCaml and Haskell were too hard to write and didn't have sufficient library support.
  • They already knew Python, and would compensate for its lack of types with unit tests, and supplement it with C++ for high-speed code on the backend.

I agree with their decision. The main issue is that server time is cheaper than developer time.

A scripted language like Python (or PHP, Perl, Ruby, etc.) takes about half as much time to program as a bytecode or compiled language like Java (or C, C++, etc.).

So if you have a team of 10 developers each paid $100K, then you are paying out $1M in salaries. If you replace Python with Java, now you need to hire 10 more developers, and pay out another $1M. In exchange for what, saving $50K of server time? Obviously, that's not worth it!

The founders already knew Python and were ready to go with it. They wanted to get to market as soon as possible to have an early mover advantage. And they knew that they could find out where to optimize once the site was already in production and its features had been decided on. At that time, they could switch to C++ on the back end.

This is a good example for other startups. The combination of rapid development time and flexibility on the front end and speedy service time on the backend is a good example to imitate.

I wrote NVM for Windows in Go. I’d never written Go code before that project. Today that project is used by 1.5M users that I’m aware of (probably more since it’s syndicated). From a productivity perspective, that’s pretty useful.

Update (2/4/20)
I didn’t like the UI or the experience of using Go’s native docs, and I’m not wild about godocs “wall of text” either. I decided to do something about it. I’ve started working on Metadoc, a collaborative documentation platform, in response to this (starting with, you guessed it, Go).

Hadoop became obsolete.

To be clear, Hadoop is an entire ecosystem for handling storage and analysis of “big data”, with several important layers like HDFS (a file system to store data reliably across many servers) and MapReduce (algorithms to run large distributed queries reliably across that stored data).

It was a great innovation when launched from Yahoo’s research in 2006, which itself was based on Google’s internal projects from even earlier. Back then Hadoop was the only solution for companies that needed to handle big data, and it had a proven history in those large internet and software companies even if it was difficult to deploy and operate. That gap became a business opportunity and quickly led to three large vendors (Cloudera, Hortonworks, MapR) all vying to bring it to the masses.

Unfortunately for them, the next innovation was AWS and cloud computing which ushered in a new era of cheap commodity computing and storage that was cheaper and more scalable than Hadoop could ever be. Object storage like S3 provided a simple API without the complex file management. Data warehouses like Redshift and Bigquery offered faster analysis using standard SQL without the convoluted MapReduce baggage.

The industry is only getting more streamlined as Kafka and streaming architectures take shape, Spark and machine-learning workflows get faster and more reliable, and newer upstarts like Snowflake Data and MemSQL offer fantastic wholistic database products that can handle the entire lifecycle from ingestion, to transformation, to analysis and AI-drive insights.

Some great answers already. The modularity of Hadoop allowed detaching storage from compute and run workloads like Spark against cloud storage such as AWS S3 and Google Cloud Storage, instead of HDFS.

It might not seem like a big deal, but in fact, it’s THE BIG DEAL.

Let’s do the math. Storing (just storing!) 1Tb of data for a year in S3 would cost you $276/year.

One external programmer hired by my employer managed to produce 5 pages of SQL code to calculate a geometric mean.

To refresh everyone’s memory, the geometric mean of n values is the n-th root of the product of these values.

So, yes, doing this directly in SQL is quite tricky, as multiplication is not one of the standard aggregation functions. He managed to write beautiful SQL code using all kinds of advanced techniques to calculate the geometric mean. Truly wonderful code which was, unsurprisingly, slow as all hell.

And the catch? He failed to realize that if you take the logarithm of the geometric mean of some column x you get the standard arithmetic mean (i.e., the sum of the values divided by n) of the logarithm of the values in x. In other words, this:

  1. SELECT EXP(AVG(LOG(x))) FROM tbl

is all you need to calculate the geometric mean of the values stored in column x in table tbl.

The left hand side of this is the geometric mean of {xi}ni=1{xi}i=1n. The first equals sign holds because exponentiation and the logarithm (by which I mean the natural logarithm) are each other’s inverses. The second equals sign holds because (ab)c=abc(ab)c=abc. And the third equals sign holds because log(ab)=loga+logblog⁡(ab)=log⁡a+log⁡b. Finally, the right hand side of this is equal to the exponential of the arithmetic mean of the logarithm of {xi}ni=1{xi}i=1n. And that is exactly what the SQL statement is saying as well.

I've made my fair share of mistakes but I enjoy thinking back to the successes (especially complex ones that keep my interested in this field). Yet, this faux pas to be kind in description was two major misunderstandings in OOP (Object Oriented Programming). This was a B2B vendor ordering system with daily status reporting on the widgets being produced and where they were in the supply chain. (Or was originally designed for that basic feature set. Hint: state machines are your friend). Once I took over the code base I noticed two blaring inaccuracies.

Both were based on the misunderstanding of the nature of the concepts of OOP and moreover, common sense missteps . I'm not hounding the developer. Drastically reduced timeframes and incomplete requirements (in a time before agile, chuckle if you like) stacked the deck against this person. I had the beauty of hindsight. First, the entire system was contained within one single class called Connection! All behavior, business rules, data transmission between PC and AS/400, as well as direct error prone status/exception reporting was a collection of dragons waiting to pounce. The entire premise of OOP is multiple class/objects and their *relationships* to define and

Where was the mistake? 4 machines meant 4 unneeded points of additional failure. And boy did it happen. If an INI failed to load properly, entire system failure. Daily hunting and fire fighting was a major annoyance until we received approval for a rewrite that yielded zero bugs from launch until at least a few months (4-6?) of increased ordering, reporting and general activity. I'm very proud of the work and resultant system we produced, limiting it to 2 beefy PC servers and our mighty AS/400. To be fair, no one’s infallible and I'll save the story of how I personally, accidentally, deleted production customer data with a single delete where clause :) So many faults in that last statement.

Good question! Games is a business just like any other industry. Don't expect to be successful right out of the gate. That's just the business world.

Take for example the show, The Profit, or Shark Tank. It's clear that companies can gross millions and their founders can still struggle.

Independent game developers are retail businesses that sell consumer entertainment products.

So I think if you view yourself in that light you'll have a good shot at success. But if you're just looking to get in quick, make it big and then exit, it's probably not going to work out so well for you. It could happen, but it probably won't.

At the end of the day, business is hard work.

• UX Designer - User experience designers think and design for the users both on the screen and off the screen. If a user interacts with it as part of their experience, it's the job of a UX professional to make sure it's great.
  • UI Designer - Designs for the pixels on the screen. They design screens and interactive elements that will generally appear on a screen. They will design the elements and states that will be on screen and how they work together.
  • IA Designer - This sub-specialty stands for: Information Architect and deals with information on screens and how they are connected. They may often work with a UI or UX designers to ensure that the flow of information moves between systems and screens correctly. It's common for many UX and UI people to do some amount of IA and it's a less common dedicated role.
  • Web Designer - This is usually a super-set of other types of designers who specialize in web-specific user interface patterns. A web-designer will also more likely be familiar with some set of technology including CSS, HTML, JavaScript, etc. Most Web Designers are doing some amount of UX/UI and IA.

Well, there are many highly reputed web design agencies you can find out there which certainly deserve to be labeled as the “Best”

But if you ask me to label one based on my own personal experience, then I must say that the best one I have ever used to design my website is Ostellar.

You know, I earn my bread and butter by doing Amazon affiliate business. And it always requires to create different websites and blogs for new niches that I began working with.

So I myself often create new websites. And to get them designed in a professional manner, I use a growing agency named Ostellar.

So I myself often create new websites. And to get them designed in a professional manner, I use a growing agency named Ostellar.

They have a team of experts who are specialized in both Web Designing and SEO optimization.

So when I opt for their Designing service, I get the SEO part done as well.

You know, I am expert in off-page SEO optimization, but to be honest, I have very little knowledge about on-page optimization.

So Ostellar does the designing and on-page optimization for my new websites. And it costs me only a little initial investment which I later make up with my affiliate sales.

So for myself, the best web designing agency is Ostellar which has never been featured on Forbes or other high-ranking portals.

But the awesome work they do for my site(s) is really appreciable. And that’s why I would like to label them as the best and most affordable one.

• The Lack of Standards: The web development service is rather new and lacks uniformity. There are multiple languages PHP, WordPress, Angular, platforms and systems that can be put to use to program a website. The multiplicity of ways to reach a single desired outcome makes it even more complex. The way one person or company develops a project may be completely different from others.
  • Complexity in Planning: Implementing a single feature in the website could take up anywhere from an hour to a hundred depending on the complexity and inputs needed. If you want users of the website to be able to publish their own content, there could be a hundred details that may be needed. Does content need approval to be published? Do you want to establish checks for plagiarism? Do you wish to include images? If images can be uploaded, what is the maximum size per image? And all features will need details. It is advised to, therefore, find an experienced and trusted team that takes these decisions for you in your company’s best interest. The prices vary accordingly.

• Continuous Time & Work: Websites are largely viewed as products but they should be categorized as service because the process of developing a website is continuous and requires time and effort of the developing team.
  • Varied Quotes: The number of web developers has increased significantly from freelancers, small companies to big corporate giants.The quotes given for the same web project can vary as much as $3,000 to $50,000 depending on the expertise of the company, the preferred platforms, the team size and even their location.

    Web development in the US can cost 4 times more than that in India with the same level of quality of work.
  • Fixed vs. Hourly Price: While some companies still give a fixed quote, most companies are shifting to an hour-based pricing model as it allows them to cover the grey areas. The fixed price model did not account that some websites that seemed simple may take up months. The hourly model accounts for the far too valuable manpower and their time.

Image Source: Raseotech

The owner/founder of the company is the best judge of what they want to achieve by enhancing their web presence.

With over 19 million websites, it is clear that the world has moved past offline.

Does your website just provide information on your product/service or do you wish to set up an online marketplace for it?

The cost of the two may differ more than you imagine.

For instance, a one-page website will cost much lesser than an enterprise website with hundreds of pages. An e-commerce website may cost even more.

Domain Name and Hosting:

The URL of your website or the domain name is the unique internet fingerprint that can be used only by you.

Other companies can take similar names but your .com (or .in, .org, etc) belongs to your company.

To ensure rights to this domain name, the name has to be registered annually and factors as a cost. This cost is generally accounted for in the maintenance cost.

The cost of domain name varies from $5 to anywhere.

A keyword containing domain name may cost even a $1000.

Website development is mostly labor on the part of the Web designer , the graphics person and management. There are generally no products involved. So what determines most of the price is how much labor there is.

The next thing is how big a site do you want? Do you need ten pages , five pages or just a brochure site? As you can imagine , ten pages takes more time than a one page brochure site. So it will be higher in price.

Do you have graphics for your site ? Do you have copy? If this has to be created , then it will take more time. My experience is that a Wordpress site will take about 120 hours or so to build if the client has the copy and the graphics.

At this time , you can expect to pay about $3000.00 US for a five page site. Usually this will include a year of hosting for the site also and maintenance of the site.

Of course, you will have to pick a designer and negotiate with him or her on the site, but there are a lot of them out there. Just make sure they have a portfolio that will give you a good idea of their work.

The average cost of a Web site is $100,000, with a margin of error of $0 to one hundred million.

I just made that up. There is no reliable average calculation, and, even if there were, it would be meaningless. It’s like asking what the average cost of a building is. I can put up a shed in my back yard for the cost of materials, or $0 if I scavenge boards myself. The Burj Khalifa, on the other hand, cost roughly $1.5 billion. The average of 0 and 1.5 billion would be $0.75 billion, which tells us exactly nothing.

The cost of a site depends entirely on what you want to build and the level of quality you expect.

std::string is a performant class with backward compatibility features to allow some inter-operability with legacy use of C-style strings.

It’s a bit of a monolith with over 100 member functions. Let’s not call it perfect.

Given the frankly egregious design of C strings - NUL terminated - the only possible reason for writing new code with old strings is a requirement for deep backward compatibility. Typically that means the C code may modify the string contents or length.

I was a die hard fan of C language back when I was in college

Even during the interviews where people are simply using python and some other high level languages to generate string permutations in one line, I still use to code in C with 50 lines.

But as industry moving towards high level languages+ Intelligent Editors to achieve faster pace of development, I fell into the same loop and I’ve thought programming is so damn easy.

But one day, during an interview it was kind of whiteboarding.

No code editors, no manuals to refer and I was asked to code for a problem statement.

But one day, during an interview it was kind of whiteboarding.

No code editors, no manuals to refer and I was asked to code for a problem statement.

I was not even able to write a single line of code, the reason being all the high level languages are abstracted in such a way that anything can be imported as a package( which we don’t remember without an IDE) and the code editors like VSCode and IntelliJ will show you all functions before hand,

There is a ton of difference between writing code vs Using Code.

That one moment I’ve understood why C is still the king of all languages and why it should be the first one to master with..

Luckily I’ve moved away from high level abstracted languages like Python, Javascript and settled with C type language called GO.

Very less abstraction and runs faster than usain bolt.

As a dinosaur C++ programmer I don’t find it difficult. I do think in some ways C++ is getting worse. Too much stuff is constantly being added to it and it just makes it more and more confusing and harder to learn for new users. This might piss off some C++ programmers but I would forgo “modern” C++ initially. In fact I would even say learn C first. From there you can can learn the older C++ features and move forward. You will have a much better understanding of the language learning it bottom up.

Remember you don’t have to use every feature. I often skip using parts of the standard library because I find them too be slower, and not only at run time. You often spend less time writing your own template than using the standard library. I have seen long discussion on how to implement something using the standard library that get into all sorts of complex details. If anyone says “hey, you know you can easily just write that yourself in a few minutes”, they are often booed out of the room.

Bottom line, when programming in C++ don’t make your life harder by being a C++ prima donna and trying to use the latest greatest tricks. Concentrate on algorithms and data structures. That’s what’s important in any language.

Finally since you brought up Swift and Java, I really don’t think the performance is up to C++ level. Sure you can find benchmarks that claim that it is, but experience C++ programmers use things like custom heaps, and implement their own reference counting (rather than using the slowish shared_ptr). I’ve really never seen Java perform like C++ in any real applications that I’ve worked on. Every few years I benchmark it, but the bottom line is byte code (even JIT) compilation and GC have some limitations.

In my experience, nobody who claims to be an expert in a programming language is anything of the sort.

People who have long experience with a language gain expertise only in certain areas of the language, or in certain uses.

Nobody can claim, because no one could possibly achieve, a complete mastery of everything that could be done with a programming language.

So, when is it safe to say you’re “experienced” in a language?

Never.

At most you can say you have experience in using certain parts of the language in certain types of problems.

This is a question that is important to answer honestly, because otherwise you get into a job and you can’t do it, and you get sacked, and there is a lot of hard feelings, and too many people remember your name.

So, here is a rubric for experience.

  • If you have felt comfortable in the recent past writing all-new code in the language, you can say you are experienced. This is the minimum bar.
  • If you can teach the language to people who need to be up-to-speed quickly, you can definitely say you are experienced.
  • If you are one of the people that teammates come to when they have an error message they don’t understand, then you are experienced.
  • If you know where to look first when troubleshooting a bug, you are experienced.
  • If you still cannot decide, simply list your number of full-time years of experience. That’s what I do.

Broadly speaking, people would say Java is a safe language whereas, C is not.

There is no formal definition of safe programming language. By safe programming language we mean that the language is safe in some terms.

You can say C is not memory safe or Java is.
A programming language is not used to make a programming language. You have phrased your question incorrectly.

A programming language is a design specification. On paper, it can do nothing for you.

A programming language must be implemented as a compiler in order to be of any practical use. A compiler must be written in a programming language.

The most widely used language for writing compilers is C. It is the most popular choice and therefore the best.

Here’s my vote for Python. The language is relatively small and quite complete and general purpose. It manages to paper over lots of potentially nasty hardware details (like when to use a short vs. an int vs. a long vs. a long long). In Python 3 you can just expect that however big an integer value you want to store, it’s just an integer as far as your Python code is concerned - and happily, Python programs generally work out to be a lot shorter than I’d expect for whatever it is that they are written to do. That means you get from zero to clear working code in remarkably short time.

Do keep in mind that at first you have at least 2 things to learn: (1) the Python language and (2) computer programming. There are plenty of other topics to master before you’ll be fully productive. (e.g. TDD - test driven development), algorithms and data structures, available modules to draw upon from the Python library, object-oriented programming and its patterns). I was a little late to the Python party, but computer programming has kept me interested and learning for over 4 decades now.

Keep in mind that reading about a programming language

Much the same as the answer to the old question "How do you get to Carnegie Hall?" Practice, practice, practice. Here was my list of things to master: Literate Programming? - Much more to it than just the elements of the language itself. Several years later and I'm still learning and having a good time doing so. (If I was writing that article today, surely I’d replace the mention of subversion with git and github, but, hey, it’s still tools for source code version control).

Oh, and there are plenty of readily available good free online courses to help you get going.

Do not be surprised when it turns out that Python is *not* the last programming language for you to learn. Most all of your knowledge of computer programming will carry over to your next programming language, so picking up another language later on isn’t going to be as hard as you might think. So don’t overthink which language to chose, pick one and get going.

Probably the easiest is JavaScript. Hit the right key combo and you can play with JavaScript right in your browser. And you can use JavaScript to

  • Create a web app
  • Create a mobile app
  • Create a desktop app
  • Create a server for any of the above
  • Interface with IoT devices
  • Write simple command line tools
  • Access databases
  • Much more

But learning a language is never the hard part. Learning how to think like a programmer? That's the hard part.

But learning a language is never the hard part. Learning how to think like a programmer? That's the hard part.

Your first language will be painful to learn, no matter what you choose. JavaScript, Python, Swift, whatever. It won't really matter.

Though if you choose C or C++, it will be twice as hard. Fair warning.

Pick a language and learn. Build things. Quit researching what to learn and just learn one and start working on it. Anything else is just creative procrastination.

JavaScript and Python are both relatively simple just to learn. You’ll get a taste of many common programming concepts, such as data types (objects, strings, numbers, etc.), functions, OOP and control flow.

However, I would recommend starting with a statically typed language, such as Java or Go. These will force you to think more about how you are designing a program and not cut corners or make weird hacks. Go is much simpler to learn. It was not my first language, but I picked it up in a few hours. In the features that overlap with JS and Python, it’s implementation is simpler, but it does have relatively complex features like channels and Go routines that would be more difficult to learn.
I’m assuming that you’re asking this question as a beginner, because if you already know how to program with another language, then learning an additional language is no big deal.

Of all the languages I can think of, Smalltalk is by far the easiest. Its syntax is so simple and easy to learn, it’s child’s play…literally. Alan Kay, Dan Ingalls, and Adele Goldberg at Xerox PARC created Smalltalk for teaching programming to children.

Thus, it’s much easier to learn than Python or JavaScript or C or any other language you can name.

To learn Smalltalk, see Richard Kenneth Eng's answer to Which programming language should I start learning with?

And here’s the bonus: despite its simplicity and ease of learning, Smalltalk is endlessly versatile. It can be used for nearly anything! Web, desktop, mobile, data science, machine learning, IoT, embedded, robotics, virtual reality, enterprise computing…you name it. Here’s a more complete explanation: Richard Kenneth Eng's answer to What is the essence of Smalltalk?

1. Python

These days, Python is regarded as one of the best and easiest programming languages for beginners, and it gets mentioned very soon in any coding discussion. Guido van Rossum developed Python in 1980s. It’s a free and open source language that’s known for its dynamic, flexible, object-oriented, procedural, and functional programming styles.

With its simple and readable code, the programmers can express the concept in lesser lines of code. Today, it has become one of the most popular introductory programming languages in American and European schools.

Django is a powerful web framework for Python that’s widely used to power different applications.

Application of Python: Python is used to create desktop and web apps. Apart from that, it’s also a major tool in the field of machine learning, data mining, scientific computing, etc.

2. Ruby

Ruby, a dynamic, general-purpose language, was designed and developed by Yukihiro Matsumoto in 1990s, with a focus on the syntax that was easy to read by humans. This language supports multiple programming paradigms, including object-oriented, functional, and imperative. This feature makes it a very flexible programming language.

Just like Python, it’s simple and readable. As a result, it’s widely regarded as one of easiest programming languages to learn. If you already know Ruby, you might be knowing that without any need to learn tons of commands and jargon, you can get started. Just like Python, Ruby also enjoys the love of its dedicated community. Ruby acts as a great tool if you need to deal with the backend aspect of your work. It’s widely used to develop websites, web-based applications, and mobile applications.

Ruby on Rails is a web framework built on Ruby. In recent times, we’ve seen a great rise in the number of Ruby on Rails job opportunities in new startups.

Application of Ruby: As said above, Ruby on Rails is used to create web applications. Within a few minutes, one can create a web blog.

3. Java

Java was developed by James Gosling at Sun Microsystems in 1990s. Today, it’s maintained by Oracle. It’s a general purpose programming language that’s used to build different kinds of apps and software. Over the time, it has established itself as one of the most influential and solid programming languages. It’s a class-based, object-oriented programming language that’s built for portability and cross-platform application.

A lot of Java syntax is based on C or C++. That’s why it’s introduced at a later stage in schools. But, it allows a learner to think like a programmer and understand how a PC processes information. Learning Java ensures a solid foundation and makes you ready for a coding career.

Hadoop is a popular Java-based framework that used by big enterprises.

Application of Java: Java is used to build native Android applications. It’s also used as a server-side language.

4. C and C++

C and C++ programming languages, probably the first ones you learned, have been around for a very long time. C is still a widely popular general-purpose programming language that has influenced many other modern programming languages, including C++. Some people might argue that C uses more complex code compared to others, so what’s the use of C in this list? It’s one of the most fundamental languages in computer science, and learning it will make your basics clear.

Based on C, C++ is a powerful programming language that’s designed to take things one step further, and it offers object-oriented programming. It has established itself as one of the most important programming languages around. Just like C, C++ helps you gain an insight of how things work in computer science.

Applications of C and C++: These languages have been used to build numerous pieces of software, operating systems, desktop apps, mobile apps, web apps, game, game engines, etc.

5. JavaScript

JavaScript is often, and rightly, called the language of the web. The beginners shouldn’t confuse it with Java. It’s primarily a client side scripting language that’s used for front-end development. It’s easy to learn, but not as easy as Python and Ruby on Rails. JavaScript’s syntax is similar to C. Due to its cross-platform nature, it’s a widely popular programming language that’s easy to learn. It’s supported by all web browsers. Using Node.js, it can also be used as a server-side language.

Talking about a shortcoming, being an untyped programming language, JavaScript doesn’t get recommendations the way Python and Ruby get. Due to this shortcoming, the errors aren’t revealed until runtime. But, for an introduction to the world of programming, JS is a good choice.

JavaScript, one of the greatest and easiest programming language for beginners, is used often through libraries like JQuery and frameworks like React and AngularJS.

Applications of JavaScript: It’s used for web development. It’s run by most modern browsers. JavaScript is also used for mobile app development and web apps.

Good heavens there are some diverse answers here…. If you can make it to the bottom of mine, thank you!

TL;DR: Start with HTML, CSS, Javascript, and then choose another language like Perl, Java, or maybe C++.

All these other answers are good, but almost all are promoting the hard route. And ultimately, you’ll have to take the hard route at some point- but you don’t want to start out driving a car by attempting to race Ferraris. However, you also don’t have to study the history of the automobile and Thermodynamics to start Driver’s Ed. The hardest part about learning to program is staying motivated- it is too easy to say ‘this is too hard/not my thing’ and give up. DONT’ DO THAT. By starting out slow and simple, you can learn the boring bits and get them out of the way.

In my opinion, I wouldn’t touch C, C#, C++, and certainly not Assembly until you have a good grasp on the basic foundations of programming, i.e. the logic behind all of it. The baby steps of programming are Classes, Variables (Strings, Ints, Floats, more), Logic (Booleans and Conditional Statements), Loops (For, While, Do While, etc.), Functions/Methods/Subroutines, and things like Input and Output (and much much more). You’re not going to become a developer in a day, so accept the fact that you need to start simple and start small. That’s okay!

I’m guessing you want to

1.)write a bunch of code and

2.) see it do stuff.

3.) feel accomplished and motivated

Fantastic! A really really good starting place is these three: HTML(5), CSS, and Javascript. HTML is the foundation for almost every webpage you visit. All the nice text boxes, the content, pictures, and more- is done with HTML. CSS is used to style it all and make it look pretty. Neither of those are actual ‘languages’ per se…. but Javascript is. Javascript uses all of the parts mentioned in the above Baby Steps. Javascript is like the engine in a car, HTML is like the chassis and structure of the car, and CSS is like the wiring, paint job, peripherals, lights, hubcaps, etc. All three will give you a very basic webpage, but will get you past the first couple of hurdles of learning programming.

Broadly speaking, people would say Java is a safe language whereas, C is not.

There is no formal definition of safe programming language. By safe programming language we mean that the language is safe in some terms.

You can say C is not memory safe or Java is.
A programming language is not used to make a programming language. You have phrased your question incorrectly.

A programming language is a design specification. On paper, it can do nothing for you.

A programming language must be implemented as a compiler in order to be of any practical use. A compiler must be written in a programming language.

The most widely used language for writing compilers is C. It is the most popular choice and therefore the best.

Happy coding…!

Here’s my vote for Python. The language is relatively small and quite complete and general purpose. It manages to paper over lots of potentially nasty hardware details (like when to use a short vs. an int vs. a long vs. a long long). In Python 3 you can just expect that however big an integer value you want to store, it’s just an integer as far as your Python code is concerned - and happily, Python programs generally work out to be a lot shorter than I’d expect for whatever it is that they are written to do. That means you get from zero to clear working code in remarkably short time.

Do keep in mind that at first you have at least 2 things to learn: (1) the Python language and (2) computer programming. There are plenty of other topics to master before you’ll be fully productive. (e.g. TDD - test driven development), algorithms and data structures, available modules to draw upon from the Python library, object-oriented programming and its patterns). I was a little late to the Python party, but computer programming has kept me interested and learning for over 4 decades now.

Keep in mind that reading about a programming language

Much the same as the answer to the old question "How do you get to Carnegie Hall?" Practice, practice, practice. Here was my list of things to master: Literate Programming? - Much more to it than just the elements of the language itself. Several years later and I'm still learning and having a good time doing so. (If I was writing that article today, surely I’d replace the mention of subversion with git and github, but, hey, it’s still tools for source code version control).

Oh, and there are plenty of readily available good free online courses to help you get going.

Do not be surprised when it turns out that Python is *not* the last programming language for you to learn. Most all of your knowledge of computer programming will carry over to your next programming language, so picking up another language later on isn’t going to be as hard as you might think. So don’t overthink which language to chose, pick one and get going.

Several years later and I'm still learning and having a good time doing so. Probably the easiest is JavaScript. Hit the right key combo and you can play with JavaScript right in your browser. And you can use JavaScript to

  • Create a web app
  • Create a mobile app
  • Create a desktop app
  • Create a server for any of the above
  • Interface with IoT devices
  • Write simple command line tools
  • Access databases
  • Much more

But learning a language is never the hard part. Learning how to think like a programmer? That's the hard part.

But learning a language is never the hard part. Learning how to think like a programmer? That's the hard part.

Your first language will be painful to learn, no matter what you choose. JavaScript, Python, Swift, whatever. It won't really matter.

Though if you choose C or C++, it will be twice as hard. Fair warning.

Pick a language and learn. Build things. Quit researching what to learn and just learn one and start working on it. Anything else is just creative procrastination.

JavaScript and Python are both relatively simple just to learn. You’ll get a taste of many common programming concepts, such as data types (objects, strings, numbers, etc.), functions, OOP and control flow.

However, I would recommend starting with a statically typed language, such as Java or Go. These will force you to think more about how you are designing a program and not cut corners or make weird hacks. Go is much simpler to learn. It was not my first language, but I picked it up in a few hours. In the features that overlap with JS and Python, it’s implementation is simpler, but it does have relatively complex features like channels and Go routines that would be more difficult to learn.
I’m assuming that you’re asking this question as a beginner, because if you already know how to program with another language, then learning an additional language is no big deal.

Of all the languages I can think of, Smalltalk is by far the easiest. Its syntax is so simple and easy to learn, it’s child’s play…literally. Alan Kay, Dan Ingalls, and Adele Goldberg at Xerox PARC created Smalltalk for teaching programming to children.

Thus, it’s much easier to learn than Python or JavaScript or C or any other language you can name.

To learn Smalltalk, see Richard Kenneth Eng's answer to Which programming language should I start learning with?

And here’s the bonus: despite its simplicity and ease of learning, Smalltalk is endlessly versatile. It can be used for nearly anything! Web, desktop, mobile, data science, machine learning, IoT, embedded, robotics, virtual reality, enterprise computing…you name it. Here’s a more complete explanation: Richard Kenneth Eng's answer to What is the essence of Smalltalk?

1. Python

These days, Python is regarded as one of the best and easiest programming languages for beginners, and it gets mentioned very soon in any coding discussion. Guido van Rossum developed Python in 1980s. It’s a free and open source language that’s known for its dynamic, flexible, object-oriented, procedural, and functional programming styles.

With its simple and readable code, the programmers can express the concept in lesser lines of code. Today, it has become one of the most popular introductory programming languages in American and European schools.

Django is a powerful web framework for Python that’s widely used to power different applications.

Application of Python: Python is used to create desktop and web apps. Apart from that, it’s also a major tool in the field of machine learning, data mining, scientific computing, etc.

2. Ruby

Ruby, a dynamic, general-purpose language, was designed and developed by Yukihiro Matsumoto in 1990s, with a focus on the syntax that was easy to read by humans. This language supports multiple programming paradigms, including object-oriented, functional, and imperative. This feature makes it a very flexible programming language.

Just like Python, it’s simple and readable. As a result, it’s widely regarded as one of easiest programming languages to learn. If you already know Ruby, you might be knowing that without any need to learn tons of commands and jargon, you can get started. Just like Python, Ruby also enjoys the love of its dedicated community. Ruby acts as a great tool if you need to deal with the backend aspect of your work. It’s widely used to develop websites, web-based applications, and mobile applications.

Ruby on Rails is a web framework built on Ruby. In recent times, we’ve seen a great rise in the number of Ruby on Rails job opportunities in new startups.

Application of Ruby: As said above, Ruby on Rails is used to create web applications. Within a few minutes, one can create a web blog.

3. Java

Java was developed by James Gosling at Sun Microsystems in 1990s. Today, it’s maintained by Oracle. It’s a general purpose programming language that’s used to build different kinds of apps and software. Over the time, it has established itself as one of the most influential and solid programming languages. It’s a class-based, object-oriented programming language that’s built for portability and cross-platform application.

A lot of Java syntax is based on C or C++. That’s why it’s introduced at a later stage in schools. But, it allows a learner to think like a programmer and understand how a PC processes information. Learning Java ensures a solid foundation and makes you ready for a coding career.

Hadoop is a popular Java-based framework that used by big enterprises.

Application of Java: Java is used to build native Android applications. It’s also used as a server-side language.

4. C and C++

C and C++ programming languages, probably the first ones you learned, have been around for a very long time. C is still a widely popular general-purpose programming language that has influenced many other modern programming languages, including C++. Some people might argue that C uses more complex code compared to others, so what’s the use of C in this list? It’s one of the most fundamental languages in computer science, and learning it will make your basics clear.

Based on C, C++ is a powerful programming language that’s designed to take things one step further, and it offers object-oriented programming. It has established itself as one of the most important programming languages around. Just like C, C++ helps you gain an insight of how things work in computer science.

Applications of C and C++: These languages have been used to build numerous pieces of software, operating systems, desktop apps, mobile apps, web apps, game, game engines, etc.

5. JavaScript

JavaScript is often, and rightly, called the language of the web. The beginners shouldn’t confuse it with Java. It’s primarily a client side scripting language that’s used for front-end development. It’s easy to learn, but not as easy as Python and Ruby on Rails. JavaScript’s syntax is similar to C. Due to its cross-platform nature, it’s a widely popular programming language that’s easy to learn. It’s supported by all web browsers. Using Node.js, it can also be used as a server-side language.

Talking about a shortcoming, being an untyped programming language, JavaScript doesn’t get recommendations the way Python and Ruby get. Due to this shortcoming, the errors aren’t revealed until runtime. But, for an introduction to the world of programming, JS is a good choice.

JavaScript, one of the greatest and easiest programming language for beginners, is used often through libraries like JQuery and frameworks like React and AngularJS.

Applications of JavaScript: It’s used for web development. It’s run by most modern browsers. JavaScript is also used for mobile app development and web apps.
